document.docAuthor: Zeina, Amr F. & Guerra, José M.
document.masterDocTitle: Caprellidae (Crustacea: Peracarida: Amphipoda) from the Red Sea and Suez Canal, with the redescription of Metaprotella africana and Paradeutella multispinosa

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Caprellidae (Crustacea: Peracarida: Amphipoda) from the Red Sea and Suez Canal, with the redescription of Metaprotella africana and Paradeutella multispinosa

bibRefCitation.author: Schellenberg
bibRefCitation.refString: Schellenberg, A. (1928) Report on the Amphipoda. Zoological results of the Cambridge expedition to Suez Canal, 1924. Transactions of the Zoological Society of London, 22, 633 - 692. http: // dx. doi. org / 10.1111 / j. 1096 - 3642.1928. tb 00209. x

subSubSection.paragraph: Material examined. Male “a”, female “b”, 2 males (one of them lacking head), 1 female (ZMB 21555 ) collected during the Cambridge Suez Canal Expedition; 2 males and 1 female (ZMB 17533 ) collected from Suez by E. Bannwarth in 1914 (see remarks for discussion about the type material )
Description. Male “a” (ZMB 21555 )

Body length 5.4 mm . Head with a dorsal acute projection; suture between head and pereonite 1 non -marked. Pereonite 1 with a dorsal acute projection. Pereonite 2, 3 and 4 with two dorsal acute projections forwardly and another dorsal acute projection backwardly . Pereonite 2 , with a lateral projection proximally and other projection near the coxa, both of them forwardly . Pereonite 3 with a lateral proximal projection and other projection near the gill insertion. Pereonite 4 with a small rounded projection proximally and other projection near the gill insertion. Pereonite 5 with a proximal lateral projection and two dorsal projections. Pereonite 6 with a dorsal small projection. Pereonite 7 with a small projection near the coxa of pereopod 7 . Eyes distinct, small . Gills on pereonites 3 and 4 , oval, length 2 times width.

Mouthparts. Upper lip symmetrically bilobed , without setulae . Lower lip broken. Mandibles with no sign of mandibular molar ; left mandible with incisor 5 -toothed, lacinia mobilis 5 -toothed followed by three plates ; right mandible with incisor 5 -toothed, lacinia mobilis transformed into a plate , followed by other plate ; molar flake absent; palp three - articulate , second article with a single seta, third article with a distal robust setae ( like a knob) and a setal row formula 1 -x - 1 , being x= 7 in left mandible and x= 8 in right mandible . Maxilla 1 outer lobe carrying 6 robust seta; distal article of the palp with 4 setae. Maxilla 2 inner lobe triangular , with 4 setae; outer lobe rectangular , about 1.5 times as long as inner lobe , with 4 setae. Maxilliped inner plate small and rounded with 2 setae; outer plate elongate , 3 times as long as the inner plate , with 5 setae; palp 4 - articulate , dactylus curved ( falcate ) with row of setulae .

Antenna 1 about 3 ⁄ 4 of body length ;
flagellum
10 - articulate . Antenna 2 , about 0.4 x antenna 1 length , without swimming setae,
flagellum
two - articulate , peduncular article 1 with a distal projection.
Pereopods 3 and 4 minuscule ( smaller than 0.1 mm ), 1 - articulate , elongate , provided with two distal setae. Pereopods 5, 6 and 7 lacking (missing also in all the specimens examined)
Penes large , length about 2 times width.
Abdomen without clear appendages, with a pair of lateral lobes well marked and setose, and a single dorsal lobe provided with a pair of plumose setae.
Female “b” (ZMB 21555 )

Similar to holotype male apart from the following characters:
flagellum
of antenna 1 with 8 articles ; gnathopod 2 without projections on basis and ischium, propodus lacking hump and the medial projection smaller than in male ; oostegites on pereonite 3 very setose, on pereonite 4 scarcely setose; abdomen without well marked setose lobes .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8. Lateral view figures of male “a” and female “b” (ZMB 21555) of
Paradeutella multispinosa

FIGURE 9. Mouthparts of male “a” of
Paradeutella multispinosa
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Schellenberg ( 1928 ) in the original description of
P. multispinosa
reported the following material : 1 young specimen 3 mm from Km 76 (Ferry Port); several males 3.5–5.5 mm and young specimens, 3 female with brood -sac 3.5–4 mm from K. 0 (Kabret); 1 female with brood -sac 3.5 mm from K. 13 ( Little Bitter Lake); 1 male 5 mm Km. 157 ( El Shatt).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10. Antenna 1, 2, gnathopod 1, 2 of male “a” and gnathopod 2 of female “b” of
Paradeutella multispinosa
.

FIGURE 11. Pereopods 3, 4 and abdomen of male “a” and abdomen of female “b” of
Paradeutella multispinosa
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
McCain & Steinberg ( 1970 ) pointed out that the type material was deposited at the Museum für Naturkunde, Berlin . All the material of this species deposited at the Museum has been examined. The museum houses two lots of specimens (ZMB 17533 and ZMB 21555 ) of
P. mutispinosa
. ZMB 17533 contain material ( 2 males and 1 female , see
Fig. 12 lower
) collected by E. Bannwarth ( 21 February 1914 ). This material was collected from Suez and in the database of the Museum is considered as unspec. Typus. The other lot (ZMB 21555 ) comprises 3 males ( 1 of them very damaged, lacking head) and 2 females and, according to the label and database, it was collected during the Cambridge Expedition to the Suez Canal ( 1924 ). Schellenberg ( 1928 ) describes this species as part of the report on the Amphipoda collected during Cambridge Expedition to the Suez Canal but he only figured the lateral view and ganthopod 2 of one adult male ( Schellenberg , 1928 , fig. 209 ). Therefore, this material collected in 1924 (ZMB 21555 ) might be part of the material in which the description of the species is based on, and could correspond with the type material . However, it seems that Schellenberg ( 1928 ) reported more material in his description than that included in the lot ZMB 21555 , which contain only 5 specimens. The other lot (ZMB 17533 ), collected previously to the Cambridge Expedition, was probably later identified as
P. multispinosa
. Therefore, it seems more adequate to consider as type material the lot ZMB 21555 . However, at the Museum records, the lot ZMB 17533 is registered as type material and we cannot discard the possibility that Schellenberg used this material collected before to describe the species. For all these reasons, we have decided not to designate a lectotype so far, but we based the descriptions on a male “a” and female “b” from the lot ZMB 21555 . Anyway, the material of both lots clearly belongs to the same species and all the specimens of both lots (except for the damaged male without head) have been figured ( male “a” and female “b” in
Fig. 8
, and the rest of specimens in
Fig. 12
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12. Lateral view figures of specimens of
Paradeutella multispinosa
. Male and female (collected during the Cambridge Suez Canal Expedition together with the male “a” and female “b”) (ZMB 21555) (upper); two males and one female, collected in 1914 (ZMB 17533) (lower).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Schellenberg ( 1928 ) considered that the rudiments of the abdominal appendages of
P. multispinosa
showed the same arrangement of setae that Mayer figures for the genus (Mayer, 1890 , plate 5 , figure 34 ). He also indicated that the mouthparts are like those shown by Mayer for the genus, but in Mayer descriptions, mouthparts of this genus are not clear .

Paradeutella
was established by Mayer ( 1890 ). McCain & Steinberg ( 1970 ) selected
Paradeutella bidentata Mayer, 1890
as the type species of the genus. At the moment, 9 species have been described for the genus
Paradeutella
:
P. armata Mayer, 1903
;
P. bidentata Mayer, 1890
;
P. bituberculata
Barnard, 1937
; P. echinata (Haswell, 1880); P. laevis Mayer, 1903 ;
P. multispinosa Schellenberg
, 1928 ;
P. serrata Mayer, 1903
, P. spinosa Mayer, 1903 and
P. tanzaniensis
Guerra-Garcia, 2001
. Most of these species are “species inquerendae” so the genus needs a full revision and all the species should be redescribed. The diagnosis of this genus is, therefore, not clear , as shown by Takeuchi ( 1993 : table 2 ). The presence⁄absence of molar and the structure of the abdomen are not clear . Mayer considered two pair of abdominal appendages in males and one pair in females (see Mayer 1890 : 8 ) but this is not clear in the figures of the species for which the abdomen is figured, such as
P. serrata
, which seems to lack these appendages (or lobes - like appendages). Mayer ( 1890 : plate 5 , fig. 34 ) also figured the abdomen of
P. bidentata
, the type species of the genus, and the appendages are not clear since they looks more like lobes . Mouthparts are not described for the type species, so it is not clear if there is molar or not.

The description of
P. multispinosa
reveal s that the mandibles lack molar , and the abdomen lacks clear appendages ( only marked lobes are present). In fact the maxilliped and other characteristics, such as the tiny pereopods 3 and 4 , the mandibular palp with setal formula 1 -x - 1 with additional distal knob, maxilliped with small inner plate and dacylus falcate , totally agree with those in the genus
Pseudaeginella
(see e.g Lacerda et al. , 2011 ). This indicates that probably the genus
Paradeutella
should be synonymised with
Pseudaeginella
. To see if the diagnostic characters of
P. multispinosa
correspond with those of the genus
Paradeutella
, we have examined the type material of
P. bidentata
, the type species of the genus, which includes 8 specimens: 1 male (ZMUC -CRU - 4758 ); 1 male , 3 females , 1 premature females and 2 juveniles ZMUC -CRU - 5822 ), all of them collected from Sri Lanka ( Ceylon ). A careful examination of the specimens revealed that the tiny pereopods 3 and 4 are present, the mouthparts are similar to those in
P. multispinosa
: inner lobe of maxilliped very reduced, dactylus of the maxilliped palp falcate ; mandibles without molar (or extremely reduced to a vestigial tip), mandibles palp with setal formula of 1 -x - 1 and short distal knob, as in
P. multispinosa
(
Fig. 9
present study), and in
Pseudaeginella
species (see e.g.
Fig. 3
C,B in Lacerda et al ., 2011 ); abdomen lacking developed appendages. Consequently , we can assess that diagnostic characters of the genus
Paradeutella
include the lack of molar in the mandibles , and lack of clear appendages in the abdomen. According to these observations, the genus
Paradeutella
could be considered as synonymous of
Pseudaeginella
. Both genera were described in the same year (Mayer, 1890 ). Several species of
Pseudaeginella
have been recently described and most of them include detailed taxonomic descriptions according to the modern taxonomy, so, in our opinion, it would be advisable to maintain
Pseudaeginella
as valid genus and
Paradeutella
(with most of the species needing a redescription) as synonymous. However, a complete redescription of type material of
Paradeutella bidentata
, together with redescriptions of the majority of species of
Paradeutella ,
which are based on very poor and incomplete descriptions, are still necessary before undertaken this synonymy to clarify the status of these
Paradeutella
species.

Guerra-Garcia ( 2001 )
included tentatively
P. tanzaniensis
inside the genus
Paradeutella
, although pointed out that the abdomen of
P. tanzaniensis
(provided with two developed appendages) was different from the abdomen of the genus (figured and described by Mayer, 1903 ).
P. tanzaniensis
has also molar so, according to the examination of
P. bidentata
,
P. tanzaniensis
should be probably transferred to other genus such as
Deutella
, or even
Protella
, but not
Paradeutella
. Similarly , Laubitz ( 1991 ) in a study of the Caprellids from the western Pacific (New Caledonia , Indonesia and the Philippines ) included figures of
Paradeutella laevis
and P. spinosa (not collected from the type locality ). In both cases, the abdomen lack clear appendages or lobe-like appendages so this agrees with
Paradeutella / Pseudaeginella
material , but there is a clear molar , and the pereopods 3 and 4 are more developed , so, at least for
Paradeutella spinosa
, the material examined of Laubitz ( 1991 ) do not belong to the genus
Paradeutella / Pseudaeginella .
Consequently , it should be transferred to other different genus, since
P. bidentata
, the type species of the genus, indicate absence of molar as diagnostic character of the genus. Furthermore, the ganthopod 2 figured for Mayer ( 1903 ) for
P. laevis
and
P. spinosa
, is totally different to the gnathopod figured by Laubitz ( 1991 ). In the case of specimens of
Paradeutella laevis
of Laubitz ( 1991 ), they could belong to the genus
Paradeutella / Pseudaeginella
( mandible is not figured by Laubitz so the molar could also be absent) but in the case of
P. spinosa
of Laubitz, this should be, without doubt, transferred to other genus, probably
Deutella
, based on the presence of molar .

Material of Mayer ( 1912 ) and
Guerra-Garcia ( 2004 )
collected from Australia and described as
Paradeutella
sp. should be also reviewed according to the diagnosis of the genus, to confirm if they belong to
Paradeutella / Pseudaeginella
or not.

In summary, a whole revision of the genus
Paradeutella
, including redescription of the type material of
P. bidentatata
and complete redescriptions based on type series or newly collected material from the type localities of
P. armata , P. bituberculata
,
P. echinata
,
P. laevis
,
P. serrata
and
P. spinosa Mayer
, is necessary to confirm is this genus should be synonymised with
Pseudaeginella
, as suggested in the present study,.

paragraph.subSubSection:
Distribution. Type locality:
Suez Canal (Kabret, Little Bitter Lake, El Shatt, and the Ferry Port). Only reported so far from the type locality

subSubSection.paragraph:
Cancer phasma
Montagu, 1804
: 66
, pl. 6 , fig. 3 .

Caprella quadrispinis
Grube, 1864
: 63
.

Protella phasma
Mayer, 1882
: 29
, pl. 1 , fig. 2 , pl. 4 , figs 1 –8, 34– 37 , pl. 5 , figs 19–21 .

Remarks. The presence of
Pseudoprotella phasma
in the Red Sea is questionable .
Kossmann ( 1880 )
described the species
Protella danae
and
Protella subspinosa
from the Red Sea remarking that both species were provided with dorsal projections similar to those present in
Protella phasma
. Mayer ( 1882 ) considered both species as juvenile forms of
Protella phasma
, which was transferred to the genus
Pseudoprotella
eight years later (Mayer, 1890 ). Mayer ( 1903 ) described
Metaprotella africana
, and under the remarks section of this species (pp. 42, 43) he mentioned that the figures and descriptions of
Kossmann ( 1880 )
were incomplete . This makes him to doubt if the material of Kossmann could belong to
Metaprotella
instead of
Pseudoprotella
.

Schellenberg ( 1928 ) reported the presence of
Metaprotella danae (Kossmann)
from the Suez Canal , considering subsequently that
P. danae
was belonging to
Metaprotella
instead of
Pseudoprotella
. In fact, he consider as possible that his material , together with the Kossmann material of
P. danae
could belong to
Metaprotella africana
. Furthermore, he also pointed that Kossmann’s
Protella subspinosa
( 1880 , p. 128 ), according to the drawing of the last two pereonites could not belong to
Metaprotella
.
Ruffo ( 1959 )
also pointed out that
M. africana
could be the same species than
M. danae
but did not established the synonym because of the lack of material . McCain & Steinberg ( 1970 , p. 74 ) maintained
P. danae
and
P. subspinosa
as synonymous of
P. phasma
, probably based on Mayer (1882, 1890).

We have not located the material described by Kossmann but we have examined Kossmann figures;
Kossmann ( 1880 )
figured a female of
P. danae
( plate XII, figs. 1–7 ) and probably a juvenile of
P. subspinosa
( plate XII, figs. 8–9 ). In
P. danae
, pereonites 6 and 7 seem to be clearly fused (
Metaprotella
) instead of separate (
Pseudoprotella
) and the mandible palp has a setal formula of 1 -x - 1 (
Metaprotella
) instead of 1 -x - 2 (
Pseudoprotella
). In
P. subspinosa
the fusion of pereonites 6 and 7 is not so clear , although a distinct tabication is not evident. The lateral view figure of the female of
P. dana
e ( plate XII, fig. 1 ) resembles the lateral view figure of
Metaprotella africana
. The mandibular palp is also similar to that in
M. africana
, but in the figure of Kossmann, setal formula is 1 - 11 - 1 ( plate XII, fig. 2 ) and in
M. africana
is 1 - 4 - 1 (see redescription of this species in the present study). Taking into account that we have not been able to find the type material of both species (
P. danae
and
P. subspinosa
), we could not assign this to any
Metaprotella
species. We agree with
Ruffo ( 1959 )
and due to the unavailability of Kossmann material and the lack of adequate figures we cannot establish the synonymy between
M. danae
and
M. africana
, and we have maintained in this study
M. africana
as valid species, suggesting that
M. danae
, similarly to P.

subspinosa
, could be considered as nomen dubium. On the other hand, although
P. danae
seems to belong clearly to
Metaprotella
, this is not totally clear for
P. subspinosa
, so we could not discard that this species could be synonymous of
P. phasma
, as Mayer pointed out. Further collections are needed to confirm if
P. phasma
is distributed in this area or not, since apart from the doubtful records of Kossmann, attributed by Mayer ( 1882 ) to
P. phasma
, there are no additional records of this species along the Red Sea.
Pseudoprotella phasma
is an Atlantic - Mediterranean species which could have reached the Red Sea throughout Suez Canal , but probably it is not well established in this region, as most of the caprellids present at the East of the Mediterraean, which are absent in the Red Sea.

Distribution. Type locality:
south coast of Devonshire, England (see McCain & Steinberg 1970 ). Other localities: North Sea from Norway to British Isles ; Eastern Atlantic from British Isles to Cape Verde; Mediterranean, Adriatic, Black and Red Seas (McCain & Steinberg 1970 ; Krapp - Schickel 1993 .
